docs.lead_paragraph: LORI A. BONALDI was making plans for post-surgery recovery when her doctor said: ''I don't want you to stay in the hospital. There are too many germs.'' Instead, he suggested that Ms. Bonaldi, 46, from Middlebury, stay at a medical hotel.

headline.main: After Surgery, a Hotel Suited for Healing

docs.abstract: Article describes amenities at Yale-New Haven Ambulatory Services Corp/Temple Recovery Care Center, medical hotel on third floor of New Haven Hotel; center is Connecticut's first and only licensed recovery care center; photos (M)
docs.snippet: LORI A. BONALDI was making plans for post-surgery recovery when her doctor said: ''I don't want you to stay in the hospital. There are too many germs.''    Instead, he suggested that Ms. Bonaldi, 46, from Middlebury, stay at a medical hotel.

docs.lead_paragraph: The top Republicans in Congress and two Democratic senators announced Saturday that they had reached an ''agreement in principle'' on a bill to help millions of elderly people buy prescription drugs. It would be the biggest expansion of Medicare since the program was created in 1965. The White House said it would join Republican leaders in an all-out effort to push the bill through Congress, where it faces opposition from some conservatives and from many Democrats.

headline.main: Deal 'in Principle' For Medicare Plan To Cover Drug Costs

docs.abstract: Congressional leaders announce agreement on bill to help millions of elderly people buy prescription drugs, biggest expansion of Medicare since program was created in 1965; Bush administration promises to help push bill through Congress, where it faces opposition from some conservatives and many Democrats; bill injects competition and market forces into Medicare and establishes new mechanism to hold down costs; Sen Edward Kennedy denounces parts of bill that would give private health insurers larger role, and says bill tilts in favor of right-wing agenda; Rep Dennis Hastert touts bill as having support of seniors' organizations, including AARP; drug benefits would start in 2006; details of legislation noted; photo (M)
docs.snippet: The top Republicans in Congress and two Democratic senators announced Saturday that they had reached an ''agreement in principle'' on a bill to help millions of elderly people buy prescription drugs. It would be the biggest expansion of Medicare...

docs.lead_paragraph: The last time Kevin Thornton had health insurance was three years ago, which was not much of a problem until he began having trouble swallowing. ''I broke down earlier this year and went in and talked to a doctor about it,'' said Mr. Thornton, who lives in Sherman, about 60 miles north of Dallas.

headline.main: For Middle Class, Health Insurance Becomes a Luxury

docs.lead_paragraph: SANJAY SAINI was not prepared for the hate mail. A radiologist at Massachusetts General Hospital, Dr. Saini thought he had found a clever way to relieve an acute shortage of specialists who could read X-rays and M.R.I. scans. The hospital would beam images electronically from some scans to India, to be worked on by radiologists there. But the arrangement, made late last year with a company in India, has touched off a minor furor. It turns out that even American radiologists, with their years of training and annual salaries of $250,000 or more, worry about their jobs moving to countries with lower wages, in much the same way that garment knitters, blast-furnace operators and data-entry clerks do.
docs.abstract: Massachusetts General Hospital deal to have X-rays and MRI scans processed in India has touched off furor, showing that even medical care is grappling with globalization that has moved many jobs abroad; doctors complain about threat to jobs and high incomes, while critics worry that foreign radiologists may not be properly trained; Indian radiologists are not currently making diagnoses because they lack state and hospital certifications and are instead doing work done by technicians in United States; back-office medical work has been moving offshore for several years now, particularly to India; graph of radiology job ads; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: YOU probably already pay a monthly fee for access to cable TV and cellphone service. Someday soon, you may also have to come up with $20 to $30 a month for access to your doctor's services, on top of any co-payments, premiums and deductibles you're already paying for health insurance. It may sound far-fetched, but it has already happened in at least three states -- Washington, Ohio and Illinois -- and health experts say it's probably starting in other places as well. And it's not the health plans or employers that are responsible. It's the doctors themselves.

headline.main: Access Fees for Doctors? Some Test the Waters

docs.abstract: Some doctors in at least three states have begun charging monthly fees for access to their services, on top of any insurance co-payments and deductibles; respond to costs that are rising faster than revenues; many health care experts say it its wrong to charge managed-care patients extra for access to their doctors; doctors say fees let them spend more time with each patient; drawing (M)

One soldier was missing. 1

docs.lead_paragraph: A YEAR-END financial review is always advisable if you want to reduce your tax bill next April, but it is especially crucial this year as the effects of three years' worth of tax legislation come into play. ''The tax act of 2003 and provisions of prior laws are all coming together,'' said Sidney Kess, a New York tax lawyer and accountant.

headline.main: Personal Business; How Tax Changes Can Help You (Hint: Plan Now)

docs.abstract: Advice on opportunities and pitfalls facing taxpayers this year as result of tax law changes; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Ellen Jean Gold, a daughter of Mari S. Gold of Manhattan and John A. Gold of Aspen, Colo., is to be married this evening to Adam Seth Lechner, the son of Mildred and Herbert Lechner of Great Neck, N.Y. Rabbi Lisa J. Grushcow will officiate at Raphael Vineyards in Peconic, N.Y. The bride, 35, is a freelance marketing consultant and a writer of educational materials in New York. She graduated from Vassar. Her father is a former president of Executive Monetary Management, an investment advisory firm in Manhattan. Her mother is the director of communications at MetroPlus Health Plan, a health insurance subsidiary of the New York City's Health and Hospitals Corporation. The bride is a stepdaughter of Barbara Gold and of Joel Ullman.

docs.lead_paragraph: Let others deride lawyers as soulless predators. Senator John Edwards, a former trial lawyer, is not only an unabashed defender of his profession, he is also portraying himself in his Democratic presidential run as a defender of the weak and the powerless and points to his years in the courtroom to prove it. In a new autobiography for the campaign season, ''Four Trials,'' to be published by Simon & Schuster on Dec. 1, Mr. Edwards puts his oft-maligned career at the forefront, telling how in his 20 years as a personal injury lawyer, he won large judgments for average people against insurance companies and big corporations.

headline.main: Edwards the Campaigner Backs Edwards the Lawyer

docs.abstract: Article explores Sen John Edwards's legal career and how it is playing on campaign trail; conservative opponents link him with frivolous lawsuits, but Edwards touts himself as friend of common man; autobiography called Four Trials is scheduled to be published in December; photo (M)
